title: BETTER HOMES AND BLUE BOXES Part III: Advanced Signalling
historical_context: This article is part of a series on blue boxing, a technique used by phreakers to manipulate telephone systems. It reflects the state of telecommunications in the late 1980s, prior to the widespread adoption of digital signaling methods.
target_audience: Phreakers, hackers, telecommunications enthusiasts, and security professionals interested in historical hacking techniques.
short_summary: This article delves into advanced blue boxing techniques, including overseas direct boxing, the International Overseas Completion Centre (IOCC), and the Rate Quote System (RQS). It provides practical examples and methods for phreakers to navigate international calling systems.
summary:
In this third installment of the 'Better Homes and Blue Boxes' series, Mark Tabas expands on the foundational knowledge of blue boxing by introducing advanced techniques for making international calls. He explains the process of overseas direct boxing, detailing how to access specific overseas gateways and the importance of using the correct country codes. The article provides practical examples, such as dialing the Pope in Rome, to illustrate the methods discussed. Tabas emphasizes the significance of routing calls through designated gateways to ensure successful connections, particularly when dealing with countries that do not support direct dialing.

Additionally, Tabas introduces the Rate Quote System (RQS), a tool used by operators to obtain rate and routing information without needing to contact a rate and route operator directly. He explains how to access RQS and utilize its features, including testing blue boxes. The article concludes with a cautionary note about the impending obsolescence of blue boxing techniques due to the adoption of Common Channel Interoffice Signalling (CCIS), which will render many of these methods ineffective. Overall, this article serves as a comprehensive guide for phreakers looking to enhance their skills in manipulating telephone systems.
